title: Internal Surface Area Evaluation of Carbon Nanotube with GCMC Simulation-Assisted N
Adsorption
abstract: adsorption on the internal and external surfaces of single-walled carbon nanotubes of the continuous model at 77 K was compared with that on the structureless graphite surface with grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation. The inapplicability of the BET analysis for evaluation of the surface area of the internal and external surfaces of the nanotube was explicitly shown and the reason was explained with the monolayer structure difference. The ordinary α

-plot analysis using the standard isotherm of the flat graphite surface did not provide a reasonable method for the internal surface area. However, if we adopt the adsorption isotherm of the internal surface of the pore width being large enough to remove the enhanced potential effect, the subtracting pore effect method (SPE-IC method) using its α

-plot gave an accurate surface area for the internal surface except for the pore width = 2 nm. The cause for the inapplicability of BET analysis was discussed with the radial distribution function of the monolayer.
text: Recently, carbon nanotubes have gathered much attention both from fundamental science and technological interests.
Carbon nanotubes have intraparticle pores whose width is in the range of micropores and mesopores which have been recommended by IUPAC;

the term “nanopores” covering both micropores and small mesopores will be used in this article. As carbon nanotubes have basically a well-defined crystalline structure, high-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HR-TEM) observation can be used to determine the nanopore structures such as the internal surface area and pore width of the intraparticle pores. However, the obtained nanotube samples have heterogeneities in the primary crystal size and their assembly structure. Also, many carbon nanotube samples have amorphous carbon and metal impurity particles. Therefore, it is not easy to determine the average information on the pore structure from HR-TEM observation. Gas adsorption has contributed to providing information on average pore structures of less-crystalline porous materials such as activated carbon.
As to activated carbon having slit-shaped micropores, the subtracting pore effect (SPE) method using high-resolution α
-plot is quite helpful to determined the pore parameters such as surface area, pore volume, and slit width.

The fundamental basis was obtained by grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation for the slit-shaped pores. In the case of the cylindrical pores, formation of the monolayer structure on the internal pore walls is quite different from adsorption in the slit pores due to the serious packing restriction.
Therefore, we wonder whether or not the SPE method for the slit-shaped pores can be applied to the cylindrical nanopores.

If the SPE method for the slit-shaped micropores is not available for the cylindrical nanopores, there is no experimental method for evaluation of cylindrical nanopore structures. Although the BET method has been widely used in the porosity evaluation, it is well-known that the routine application provides markedly erroneous information even in the slit-shaped micropores. Accordingly, the effectiveness of the SPE method for the cylindrical nanopores must be studied.
In this work, we calculated the N
adsorption isotherm in the intraparticle nanopore and on the external surface of a single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNT) with GCMC simulation and constructed an α

-plot to propose the best evaluation method of the pore structural parameters for the cylindrical pores. The proposed method is applied to the experimental data of single-walled carbon nanohorn (SWNH), providing the porosity. Also, this method can be applicable to new carbon materials prepared by use of the zeolite template.
The principle can be widely applied even to new mesoporous silicas which have been widely studied.

shows the radial distribution function of monolayerly adsorbed molecules on the perimeter of the circular tube-wall as a function of

As molecules are more packed on a more concave wall of the tube, the intermolecular distance becomes larger on the stretched
surface, as shown in Figure 11. Hence, the smaller the
value, the longer the distance to the nearest neighbor peak. The nearest neighbor distance for

= 3.0 nm is longer than that for the flat surface by 20%. This difference is an indication of the structural restriction for mutual packing in the monolayer, because the restriction for packing needs a larger area occupied by the adsorbed molecules. The second nearest neighbor distance for
= 3.0 nm is just twice that of the first nearest neighbor distance, suggesting the square packing on the real concave surface. The second nearest peak for
= 4.0 and 6.0 nm splits into two peaks, and thereby the molecular assembly of the monolayer for
= 4.0 and 6.0 nm should have a different symmetry from that for

= 3.0 nm. These peaks correspond to hexagonal closed packing and square packing, respectively. As the first and second nearest peaks of the flat surface are broader, the molecular packing should have flexibility. Therefore, the molecules in the internal space should have a more ordered structure compared with those on the flat surface, although they cannot form a close packing structure. Thus, the molecular structure for the monolayer on the internal surface of the carbon nanotube depends sensitively on the pore width, leading to a molecular structure different from that on the flat surface. These specific monolayer structures give rise to the situation that the ordinary BET analysis cannot be applied to evaluation of the internal surface of the carbon nanotubes.

Scaife, S.; Kluson, P.; Quirke, N.
Characterization of porous materials by gas adsorption. Do different molecular probes give different pore structures?
Scaife, S.; Kluson, P.; Quirke, N.

Amorphous materials are typically characterized using N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 to obtain pore size distributions.  However, higher temps. and different adsorbates could also be used.  Here, the adsorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, N2, and Ar were measured at room temp. and 77 K on the typical high surface area amorphous activated carbon AX21.  These isotherms were analyzed using d. functional theory to obtain pore size distributions and explored whether they vary with the adsorbate used or with temp.  It was found, for example, that the pore structures predicted for AX21 using N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 293 K are quite different, with CO2 showing a unimodal micropore peak at 10.3 Å not seen at 77 K by N2 or Ar.
Lastoskie, C.; Gubbins, K. E.; Quirke, N.
Pore size distribution analysis of microporous carbons: a density functional theory approach
Lastoskie, Christian; Gubbins, Keith E.; Quirke, Nicholas

The authors present an improved method, based upon d. functional theory, for the detn. of the pore size distribution (PSD) of porous sorbents.  The adsorption isotherms predicted by nonlocal mean field theory for individual slit pores are correlated as a function of pressure and pore width.  The PSD is then calcd. by fitting this correlation to the exptl. adsorption isotherm of the sorbent.  The authors apply the anal. method to adsorption data for nitrogen on several porous carbons.  The porous network is modeled as a continuous size distribution of noninteracting slit-shaped graphitic pores.  The PSDs obtained by using the Kelvin equation and using the local and nonlocal versions of the mean field d. functional theory are compared and evaluated.  Nonlocal theory provides a more accurate interpretation of the PSD than previous methods have achieved, particularly when the anal. is applied to highly microporous sorbents.
Nano-range interfacial layer upon high-pressure adsorption of supercritical gases

A new method to det. the abs. amt. of adsorption in the case of high-pressure adsorption of supercrit. gases was proposed.  The vol. of the physisorbed layer was obtained by iteration procedures using the mean d. of the adsorbed phase which was detd. with the aid of the surface excess mass isotherm on nonporous materials.  This new approach was applied to high-pressure CH4 adsorption on nonporous carbon black and microporous carbon at different temps. from 273 to 303 K, providing the thickness of the interfacial layer of physisorbed mols. from the vol. of the physisorbed layer and the external surface area.  The interfacial layer thickness of physisorbed mols. under the high-pressure gas was in the range of 1.9 to 29 nm.

Problems and ambiguities in reporting data are discussed.  Procedures and terminol. for reporting data re recommended.
Determination of pore size and pore size distribution 1. Adsorbents and catalysts

Various kinds of pores in solid materials are classified into intraparticle pores and interparticle pores according to the origin of the pores.  The structural factors of the pores are discussed as well as the methods for evaluation of the pore size distribution with mol. adsorption (mol. resoln. porosimetry), small angle X-ray scattering, mercury porosimetry, NMR, and thermoporositmetry.  Recent progresses in mol. resoln. porosimetry for micropores are stressed; this review describes new approaches such as high resoln. N2 adsorption, He adsorption at 4.2 K, and mol. simulation for the characterization of porous solids.
Specific intermolecular structures of gases confined in carbon nanospace

The role of the nanospace of activated carbon in mol. and surface sciences is described with relevance to the role of the graphite surface in surface science.  The reason why the carbon nanospace is effective for the control of gases is explained using mol. potential theory.  The following examples of organized structure formation of gases confined in carbon nanospaces, which were detd. by in situ X-ray diffraction, magnetic susceptibility, and mol. simulation techniques, are given.  Helium forms a high-d. structure in carbon nanospace at 4.2 K; the adsorbed d. is nearly twice that of the bulk liq. d.  Even at 300 K, sufficient amts. of supercrit. Xe can be adsorbed in carbon nanospace through cluster formation.  Supercrit. NO can also be adsorbed at 303 K in carbon nanospace in the form of the dimer and the highly concd. NO decomps. rapidly into N2, even at 303 K.  The solid-like ordered structures of confined water and C2H5OH are shown.  The solid-like structure of confined water is confirmed by the temp. dependence of the electron radial distribution function.

Adsorption of CO2 and SO2 on activated carbons with a wide range of micropore size distribution
Molina-Sabio, M.; Munecas, M. A.; Rodriguez-Reinoso, F.; McEnaney, B.

The adsorption isotherms of N2 at 77 K, CO2 at 251, 273 and 298 K, and SO2 at 262 and 273 K have been detd. on a series of phys. activated carbons with a wide range of micropore size distributions.  Since the series includes carbons with very high burn-off, it shows the problems involved in the characterization of microporosity in superactivated carbons.  On the other hand, the results show that the carbon surface-adsorbate interactions for SO2 at low relative pressures are weaker than for N2 and CO2, as a result of the strong adsorptive-adsorptive interactions in the bulk gas phase.

A new analysis method for the determination of the pore size distribution of porous carbons from nitrogen adsorption measurements
Seaton, N. A.; Walton, J. P. R. B.; Quirke, N.

A new anal. method has been developed for the detn. of the pore size distribution of porous carbons from N adsorption measurements.  The method is based on a mol. model for the adsorption of nitrogen in porous carbon.  It allows, for the first time, the distribution of pore sizes to be detd. over both the micropore and mesopore size ranges using a single anal. method.  In addn. to carbons, this method is also applicable to a range of adsorbents, such as silicas and aluminas.

Superhigh surface area determination of microporous solids

A new method is proposed for the measurement of sp. surface area of microporous carbons of superhigh BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) surface area.  The method (designated the subtracting pore effects (SPE) method) is based on the anal. of 2 upward swings from linearity (due to the pore effects) in the high resoln. αs plot.  The measurement of slope of the linear αs plot after subtraction of the swings gives a definite surface area, even in a microporous system.  The surface area of activated mesophase carbon microbeads with a BET surface area of 3000-4000 m2 g-1 was detd. by N2 adsorption using the SPE method.  The BET surface area obtained in the usual manner was an overestimate by ∼ 40%.  The overestimation is attributed to capillary condensation, not to enhanced micropore filling.
Setoyama, N.; Suzuki, T.; Kaneko, K.
Simulation study on the relationship between a high resolution αs-plot and the pore size distribution for activated carbon
Setoyama, Norihiko; Suzuki, Takaomi; Kaneko, Katsumi

The effects of the micropore structure of activated carbons on the high resoln. αs-plot for nitrogen adsorption isotherms were examd. with the grand canonical Monte Carlo simulation.  Adsorption isotherms of nitrogen were simulated in graphitic slit pores at 77 K as a function of the slit width (w).  As no pore effect was obsd. below P/Po=0.6 for w = 3.5 nm, αs-plots for the simulated adsorption isotherms were constructed using the std. isotherm simulated for w = 3.5 nm.  The simulated αs-plots had filling and cooperative swings which were exptl. shown in the previous works, and the shape of the simulated αs-plot varied with the micropore structure.  As the subtracting pore effect (SPE) method for the sp. surface area (SSA) detn. using the αs-plot was proposed in the previous exptl. works, the theor. ground for the SPE method was discussed.  The best evaluation method of SSA using the αs-plot was shown, almost agreeing with the SPE method.  This simulation study showed clearly that the SPE method is available for pore systems of w ≥ 0.7 nm, whereas even the SPE method underestimates the SSA of the pores of w ≤ 0.6 nm.  The obsd. swings of the αs-plot were simulated using the different micropore size distribution.  The bimodal micropore size distribution lead to both of filling and cooperative swings, while a single pore size distribution <0.9 nm gave only the filling swing.  Thus, four representative types of the αs-plot for activated carbons were proposed and it was shown how to understand the micropore size distribution through the αs-plot.

Adsorption Study of Surface and Structural Properties of MCM-41 Materials of Different Pore Sizes
Kruk, M.; Jaroniec, M.; Sayari, A.

Nitrogen adsorption measurements were performed over a wide range of relative pressures (10-6-0.995) for a series of siliceous MCM-41 samples obtained by using alkyltrimethylammonium surfactants with different chain length.  Both high- and low-pressure adsorption data were analyzed.  The pore size was shown to increase in a regular way with the chain length of the surfactant used.  Moreover, a very good correlation between the pore size and the interplanar spacing of the MCM-41 samples was obsd.  Methods used to calc. the pore diam. were critically compared, and a new procedure to est. the pore size of MCM-41 materials was proposed.  This new procedure is based on geometrical considerations of the ratio of the pore vol. to the pore wall vol. for an infinite hexagonal array of cylindrical pores.  Adsorption measurements showed that the amt. adsorbed in the low-pressure region increases with a decrease in the pore size of the samples probably because of the enhancement of the gas-surface interactions caused by an increase in the curvature of pore walls.  The adsorption energy distributions are similar for all samples studied and quite close to those previously reported for porous silica gels.  However, the adsorption energy distributions for the MCM-41 samples were exceptionally numerically stable.

Application of Large Pore MCM-41 Molecular Sieves To Improve Pore Size Analysis Using Nitrogen Adsorption Measurements
Kruk, M.; Jaroniec, M.; Sayari, A.

MCM-41 siliceous mol. sieves were used to test the applicability of the Kelvin equation for nitrogen adsorption in cylindrical pores of the size from 2 to 6.5 nm.  It was shown that the Kelvin equation for the hemispherical meniscus, cor. for the statistical film thickness, is in quite good agreement with an exptl. relation between the pore size and the capillary condensation pressure.  The agreement can be made quant. in the pore size range from ca. 2 to 6.5 nm, if a simple correction to the Kelvin equation is introduced.  The required statistical film thickness curve (t-curve) was calcd. using nitrogen adsorption data for large pore MCM-41 samples and the obtained results were extrapolated using an adsorption isotherm for a macroporous silica gel.  Moreover, an accurate anal. representation of the t-curve was found.  Since both the cor. Kelvin equation for cylindrical pores and the t-curve have simple anal. forms, they can conveniently be used in a variety of methods to evaluate porosity.  It was shown that the BJH method with the cor. Kelvin equation accurately reproduces pore sizes of MCM-41 materials.  A comparison was made between the sp. surface areas for the MCM-41 samples calcd. on the basis of the BET equation and those obtained using other independent methods.  The results strongly suggest that when nitrogen adsorption data are used, the BET method overestimates the sp. surface area of siliceous materials.  The latter conclusion was supported by the examn. of the obtained statistical film thickness curve.

Monitoring of the structure of siliceous mesoporous molecular sieves tailored using different synthesis conditions
Kruk, Michal; Jaroniec, Mietek; Ryoo, Ryong; Kim, Ji Man

The hexagonally ordered siliceous mesoporous mol. sieve MCM-41 and the disordered mesoporous mol. sieve designated as KIT-1 were studied by means of the X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy and low temp. nitrogen adsorption over a wide pressure range.  It was shown that the combination of these techniques allows for a thorough characterization of novel mesoporous materials.  A repeated pH adjustment happens to be crucial in the synthesis of MCM-41 samples of high pore size uniformity.  An addnl. influence of the salt effect (i.e. the addn. of Na4EDTA during the hydrothermal crystn.) allows one to obtain MCM-41 materials of excellent porous structures and remarkably high thermal and hydrothermal stability.  A disordered character of KIT-1, which was synthesized with an addn. of Na4EDTA to the initial synthesis gel, was supported by the fact that the sample exhibits a high pore size uniformity but yet a rather featureless XRD pattern.  It was shown that comparative methods, such as the αs-plot, are very useful for anal. of mesoporous mol. sieves, allowing for an accurate calcn. of the sp. surface area of the samples, which exhibit condensation in mesopores in the pressure range used in the std. BET method.  A method to calc. the pore diam. for MCM-41 samples from XRD and adsorption data was shown to be convenient and useful for an accurate pore size assessment.

Capillary Critical Point of Argon, Nitrogen, Oxygen, Ethylene, and Carbon Dioxide in MCM-41
Morishige, K.; Fujii, H.; Uga, M.; Kinukawa, D.

The effect of temp. on adsorption isotherms of Ar, N2, O2, C2H4, and CO2 on mesoporous MCM-41 mol. sieves with different pore sizes (pore radius rp = 1.2, 1.4, 1.8, 2.1 nm) has been measured.  The occurrence of adsorption hysteresis upon capillary condensation of these mols. in mesopores depends on their capillary crit. temps. (Tcc), which are far below the corresponding bulk crit. temps. (Tc).  In accord with theor. predictions of confined geometry effects on the criticality of fluids in narrow pores, a plot of (Tc - Tcc)/Tc against d/rp for Ar, N2, O2, and C2H4 seems to form a single straight line passing through the origin, where d is the mol. diam.  The data for CO2 deviates from this relationship.  These results are compared with crit. point shifts of fluids in conventional mesoporous adsorbents with an interconnected network of pores available in the literature.
Jaroniec, M.; Kruk, M.; Olivier, J. P.
Standard Nitrogen Adsorption Data for Characterization of Nanoporous Silicas
Jaroniec, Mietek; Kruk, Michal; Olivier, James P.

The nitrogen adsorption isotherm measured at 77 K in the relative pressure range from about 5 × 10-7 to 0.988 for a macroporous silica is reported in a tabular form.  The isotherm data are in good agreement in the high-pressure range with the ref. data published by Gregg and Sing and by Kiselev and Aristov and provide an extension of the latter data to the low-pressure region, for which a reliable ref. isotherm was not available in the literature.  Application of the currently reported ref. adsorption isotherm is discussed.  The data can be used in comparative anal. (αs-plot or t-plot) to evaluate the external surface area, micropore vol., primary mesopore vol., and total surface area as well as to analyze surface properties of silica-based materials.  The adsorption isotherm can also be applied as a statistical film thickness curve in the calcn. of the mesopore size distribution.

Computer simulations of the wetting properties of neon on heterogeneous surfaces
Curtarolo, Stefano; Stan, George; Cole, Milton W.; Bojan, Mary J.; Steele, William A.
Physical Review E: Statistical Physics, Plasmas, Fluids, and Related Interdisciplinary Topics

We use the grand canonical Monte Carlo method to study the nature of wetting transitions on a variety of heterogeneous surfaces.  The model system we explore, Ne adsorption on Mg, is one for which a prewetting transition was found in our previous simulations.  We find that the first order transition present on the flat surface is absent from the rough surface.  Nevertheless, the resulting isotherms are, in some cases, so close to being discontinuous that the distinction would be difficult to discern in most expts.

The potential energy of a gas atom interacting with a solid having a surface made up of a single type of exposed lattice plane can be expressed as a Fourier series in the position variables in the plane parallel to the surface.  Assuming that the total interaction is a pair-wise sum of gas atom-solid atom terms, an analytic expression for the Fourier coeffs. is obtained for inverse power law interactions.  Gas-solid potentials calcd. for several surface lattices by direct summation are compared with those given by the truncated Fourier series, and a satisfactory representation in the energy is obtained even when the no. of terms included is small.  The truncated series is then utilized to calc. the Henry law adsorption consts. and av. energies for an isolated adsorbed atom.  These results are compared with calcns. based on completely localized and perfectly mobile adsorption models.
